title: 109_hr826
content: The Congress finds that paraprofessionals are not substitutes for certified teachers, small class size is crucial for learning, adding more adults in the classroom improves student attention and discipline, and expanding entry-level classroom jobs can encourage more adults to enter teaching careers. Funds are allocated for recruiting, hiring, and training paraprofessionals. The Secretary of Education allocates funds under this Act to States and local educational agencies based on specific percentages. States must distribute 100 percent of the funds to local agencies, with 80 percent allocated to local educational agencies. The Secretary of Education allocates funds under this Act to States and local educational agencies based on specific percentages. 80 percent of the funds are allocated to local educational agencies based on the number of children from low-income families in the school district, while 20 percent is allocated according to other criteria. The Act aims to decrease student to personnel ratio in classrooms by funding the recruitment, hiring, and training of 100,000 new classroom paraprofessionals in public schools. Funds are allocated to local educational agencies based on student enrollments to improve educational achievement for all children. The Act allows local educational agencies to use funds for recruiting, hiring, and training paraprofessionals to assist teachers, including those in bilingual education, special education, and migrant education. Up to 25 percent of the funds can be used for providing professional development. The Act allows funds to be used for professional development opportunities for paraprofessionals, including multi-week institutes during the summer months. The Act allows funds to be used for professional development opportunities for paraprofessionals, including initiatives for retention and mentoring, and assistance for new and existing paraprofessionals to ensure they are highly qualified. The Act allows local educational agencies to use 100 percent of funds received under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 for reducing the ratio of students to instructional personnel in grades kindergarten through 3 to 18 or less. The Act allows local educational agencies to use funds to reduce student-to-personnel ratios in grades K-3, improve paraprofessional quality, and assist paraprofessionals in becoming licensed teachers. Funds must supplement, not supplant, state and local funds. The Act allows local educational agencies to use funds to reduce student-to-personnel ratios in grades K-3, improve paraprofessional quality, and assist paraprofessionals in becoming licensed teachers. Funds must supplement, not supplant, state and local funds. No funds under this Act can be used to increase salaries or provide benefits, except for professional development for paraprofessionals hired under this Act. States must report data on fund usage, services provided, and students served biennially. States and local agencies must publicly report progress in decreasing student ratios to parents. The Act allows local educational agencies to use funds to reduce student-to-personnel ratios in grades K-3 and improve paraprofessional quality. Schools must disclose staff qualifications upon request, and administrative costs are limited to 2 percent of funds. Agencies seeking funds must submit an application under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act. Under section 5133 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, agencies must describe their program to reduce student-to-personnel ratios in classrooms by recruiting, hiring, and training paraprofessionals. Definitions include paraprofessionals as individuals employed in schools under teacher supervision, with specific roles in bilingual, special, and migrant education. The terms "local educational agency," "Secretary," and "State" are also defined within the Act. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 requires agencies to outline their plan to reduce student-to-personnel ratios by hiring paraprofessionals. The term "State" is defined in relation to the Departments of Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education. $1 billion is authorized for appropriations annually from 2006 to 2010 to implement this Act.
